intro: Brassica elongata, commonly known as the wild mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with simple, alternate leaves that are lance-shaped and hairy. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. The plant produces spherical pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind.
